label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, October 3, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, discussing the possibility of not living at Medway Plantation after the war, explaining that his job as an administrative officer is more of a secretary position, and asking her if she remembered a gentleman they had met by the name of Hennings. Sidney continues in his letter to describe Morris’s illness, the mandatory black out in Hawaii, and the lack of censorship on her letters. He also discusses the war and attempts to provide her the information she needs to schedule a phone call to him.

metadata.value:

October 3, 1942
Gertie Darling, 
What a wonderful afternoon. Three of your letters
arrived[,]8,9,10. I was so excited that I did not know which one to
open first. Then when I did and found them so full of news and
your own sweet self I almost cried with pleasure. Your life sounds
terrible at night and I wish I was there to cheer you and give you
a hundred big fat kisses. However I think you are doing marvellous
work in your office and I am very proud of you. I am only sorry
you have to work so hard. 
Please do not worry about the poaching at Medway.
That seems so far away from me, and scmehow that life appears to
ne a litt1e unreal and artificial, and devoid of interest. I
don't think we will ever want to burden ourselves with plantation
troubles again, rather I want to live with you by the sea in the
sun[s]hine sorrounded by flowers , and to hell with all those pouting
spoiled negroes and the poachers that are continually overunning
ones land and ruining our rides because we always are hearing their
shots.
Gertie my job is not a big job. It is tiny and not
in anyway important. Unfortunately this is true, and I do not see
any change in the future. What I said about the possibility of
leaving this job was that men are always being detached from this
office for air duty, four more are leaving very soon. No one
knows who will be next, and it might as well be me as anyone.
The set up is such that air is the most important part of our
work and as a result even if one does not know anything about it
[End Page 1]
is presumed that you do. Morris and I are administrative officers,
and our job is to run the office and personnel. This means everything
from seeing there is a sufficent amount of paper and paper clips
to seating the officers, opening all mail and routing it, securing
transportation dictating all official correspondence etc. It
is nothing but a secretaries job , and probably the first girl you
bump into on [C]onstitut1on avenue could do the job better than.I can[,]
It is interesting only in that it keeps me very busy as there
is always someone who wants something in a great hurry[,]and then
either Morris or I cling to the telephone and dial energetically
drying to get the department that will do it. Tomorrow is our day
off as it is Sunday and we were looking forward to it as we both
have lousy colds. However the Admiral decided to make an inspection
and as we are responsible for the appearance of the office we will
have to be here. I hope he will be satisfied and not tell me
to scrub the deck.
Doyou remember a man called Hennings, very attractive,
we crossed with him on the [O]lympic the year we were married. He
is here now and recognized me the other day[,] which I think is
amazing as we had not seen one another since that time and that was
thirteen years ago. He talked about Pat Roarke and Tremaine, and
from somewhere in my mind I thought I remembered that Tremaine
was ki_lled at Dunkerque and told him so. Is that correct.
Hennings was Rex Tugwells aide in Puerto Rico, and you may remember
reading an article about him in time two years ago. He helped me
a great deal the other day taking me around to see various officers
that I would have found it difficult to contact without him, and
talking to him about the old Olynpic brought back all the memories 
[End Page 2]
of being with you. Do you remember the fun we had, and the
thrills. It all seems just like yesterday to me and I find myself
smilling sonetimes at my work when I think of it. 
Today is [S]unday and we are at the office waiting for the
Admiral to make his inspection. Morris looks as if he is going
to die he has such a bad cold and sore throat. They have given
him sulfa something or xother pills to take and he says they make
him feel even worse. I refused to take them for my cold and do not
believe I am any worse off. I wish the old man would come so I
could go home[,] but he probably will not show up until late this
afternoon. Everything is spick andspan now but by then the dust
will have blown over all the desk and there will be bits of paper
on the floor. 
We now have to black out at 7.30 and cannot turn
our lights on until 6;45 in the morning so I am graudally learning
to live like a mole and by the time the war is over will only
be able to blink whe[ne]ver I face strong light. The other evening
a gas station had forgotten to turn its neon lights out at seven
thirty and there was an immense-crowd around the light ahing and
oh-ing about how wonderful it was. Really it was extraordinary how
gay it seemed, you do not realise how much you live in the darkness
until you see something like this. Anyway Morris the goodSmaritian
climbed up and disco_nnectedthe light and the crowd booed because
they did not care if the owner would be fined $100 bucks as long
as they could see the light for a little while.
The wild smoke turkey that you are sending
us for thanksgiving sounds marvellous. But please do not think
the food here is bad. It is very good, and all that one can eat.
I have not weighed since I left America but I know that I have not
[End Page 3]
lost , and certainly the seat of my trousers has broad[e]ned as a
result of so much sitting.
None of your letters are censored, nd I do not believe
that mall from the mainland is. Only what we send out from here
is opened and read. This is what c[A]sues the delay sometimes.
However what I can not understand is how one day you will receive
a letter from me that has only taken four days and thena_nother
time it will take 15 days.
I was so amused about [B]en's immenient departure. I
would not worry my sweet about Carola going to England until you
hear she has gone. England seems so far away out here and we
get only the mostfragmentary reports about the Russian war. I
have not seen the word Meditaranean for weeks so do not even know
whether the Libyian campaign is still on or whether it is finished.
The war with Japan is the one source of military conversation I hav[e]
heard and I have not heard a great deal about that. Certainly not
half asmuch as Iwould read in Time or Life. I am afraid that I
cannot see the woods for the trees, and that I know more about
paper clips thaxn I do about the armed forces.
When you put in your call on Susday the 11th. please
tell theoperator youwant to speak to me at either 1 PM or 8 or 6AM.
As I told you in my last letter they called me at ten thirty and
as a result I sat in my room waiting. Not that I mind this but
it seemed so indefininte [as] I did not know when you would really
call. Certainlyif I am transferred I will call you, but do not
think I will be able to tell you where I am going or any plans,
axs that would be against the censorship. My hotel [telephone] number is
9934. There is no exchange out here you just give that numbgr to
[End Page 4]
the operator and you will get the hotel. Then my room number is
15-1, but that is not necessary as the hotel oeprator will connect
me with you. I can hardly wait to speak to youagain even though
we are unable to say anything that makes sense.
It is now noon and the Admiral has not come yet. I guess
he will not turn up today at all. It does'nt bother me however,
I have become very fatalistic which isthe samething as lazy, and if
I had taken the day off I probably would have been burned too
much by the sun or someth[i]ng else would have happeneded.
Morris thanks youso muohh for wishing him a happy
birthday and will start wishing you one now in order that it may
arrive in time.
Goodbye dear, I send you all my love
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 5]
